user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_demove:
```c
static int lfs_fs_demove(lfs_t *lfs) {
    if (!lfs_gstate_hasmove(&lfs->gdisk)) {
        return 0;
    }

    // Fix bad moves
    LFS_DEBUG("Fixing move {0x%"PRIx32", 0x%"PRIx32"} 0x%"PRIx16,
            lfs->gdisk.pair[0],
            lfs->gdisk.pair[1],
            lfs_tag_id(lfs->gdisk.tag));

    // no other gstate is supported at this time, so if we found something else
    // something most likely went wrong in gstate calculation
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_tag_type3(lfs->gdisk.tag) == LFS_TYPE_DELETE);

    // fetch and delete the moved entry
    lfs_mdir_t movedir;
    int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &movedir, lfs->gdisk.pair);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // prep gstate and delete move id
    uint16_t moveid = lfs_tag_id(lfs->gdisk.tag);
    lfs_fs_prepmove(lfs, 0x3ff, NULL);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &movedir, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_DELETE, moveid, 0), NULL}));
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_fs_demove:
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_mdir {
    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    uint32_t rev;
    lfs_off_t off;
    uint32_t etag;
    uint16_t count;
    bool erased;
    bool split;
    lfs_block_t tail[2];
} lfs_mdir_t
...
static int lfs_dir_commit(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_mdir_t *dir,
        const struct lfs_mattr *attrs, int attrcount) {
    int orphans = lfs_dir_orphaningcommit(lfs, dir, attrs, attrcount);
    if (orphans < 0) {
        return orphans;
    }

    if (orphans) {
        // make sure we've removed all orphans, this is a noop if there
        // are none, but if we had nested blocks failures we may have
        // created some
        int err = lfs_fs_deorphan(lfs, false);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &movedir, lfs->gdisk.pair);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario:
No: in this call the pointer usages are appropriate. The second argument (&movedir) is a non-const lfs_mdir_t* because the function is expected to populate/modify movedir. The third argument (lfs->gdisk.pair) should be passed as a pointer-to-const (and in the LittleFS API lfs_dir_fetch takes const lfs_block_t pair[2]), so the call itself does not violate Rule 8.13. 

(Only a violation would occur if lfs_dir_fetch were declared to take a non-const pointer for the pair argument even though it does not modify the pair; in that hypothetical case the function signature—not this call—would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.)
